Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2012 05:33PM lamuso wrote: Butterfly....sending hugs your way.   I'm sorry you are dealing with this stupid cancer again.  It sucks, no doubt about it but you can do it.  Your kids love you and need you around for a long time to come. One day at a time.  I'll be praying everything goes as well as possible for you!
Posts.Title: Stage 3 again 6 years later ButterflyLady Kodapants

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2016 10:19PM lamuso wrote: I've had lymphedema for 8 years now. Having a flare up that's been getting me down.  Been going to therapy since November.  I've seen some upper arm improvement but my right, lower arm is where I seem to have most my problems.  I wrap at night in layers and I wear a sleeve during the day.  Still my arm is fighting against me to stay large and puffy looking.  Getting kind of dowm.

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2009 08:55AM lamuso wrote: Isn't that the truth.  I think I lived in a dream like state for a long time.  It is all so much to take in but we get through it one day at a time.  I thank God for my family and friends during this time.  They continue to be a strength of support even now when I am stronger and doing very well.
Posts.Title: I didn't know my own strength - whitney houston lyrics everyminute alaskalady

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2011 08:08PM lamuso wrote: Weesa, I am in the same boat as you.  I have the best of intentions and sometimes I follow through.....but tonight I was on my deck enjoying several Coors Lites with my hubby.  That seems to be the case more often than not.
Posts.Title: I'm fially coming out of the closet as a slouch. weesa faithfulheart

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2010 04:53AM lamuso wrote: Hello Bluesky.  I am sorry to hear you lost your job.  I am two years out from chemo.  I have a difficult time with my short term memory.  I work in a school setting (high school math) and it can be very frustrating at times.  At home in casual conversation with my husband and kids I often forget what we are talking about in the middle of a conversation.  Yes, some of this is due to my wandering mind.... but I never had memory issues like I do now.  My oncologist doesn't believe in memory loss due to chemo so this adds to my stress.  I am 48 and I wonder if this is just 'getting older' stuff.  I'm still convinced chemo has played in to this though.  Have you asked your oncologist about this?  I have a friend who sees a different oncologist in the same building who does believe the chemo does something with memory.... short term particularly.
Posts.Title: Foggy Brain-3 Years After Chemo Treatment bluesky Joviangeldeb

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2011 10:34PM lamuso wrote: I used to get that question a lot when I was first diagnoised.  And I do believe what they are asking is if it is treatable or not.  Most people don't mean to be insensitive but if they haven't been where we are what they believe to be an innocent comment can make us angry or depressed for the rest of the day.   I had one guy tell me his sister was diagoised, was told she was would be fine, and was dead a year later.  I mean really?  I was newly diagnoised at the time and his comment crushed me.  He wasn't a friend of mine....just someone who slightly knew me and had heard of my diagnosis and felt the need to share.  Thank goodness most people aren't as insensitive.
Posts.Title: How do you answer "did they catch it early?" oaktownmom 208sandy

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2011 08:55PM lamuso wrote: Weesa, I had high calcium show up on my blood test about 6 months ago.  My onc. dr. wasn't worried.  He told me to cut down on the amount of calcium supplements I was taking.  I cut back by one pill and the last two appointments showed normal calcium levels. Has your dr. asked you about your calcium intake?  Leslie :)

I can relate to and have done many of the things you gals mention in your postings above.

Posts.Content: lamuso wrote: I have a question about staging.  I was given chemo before my mastectomy.  My tumor shrank to 2cm during this time.  Before chemo the MRI led us to believe the tumor was 5 cm.  Is my staging done from the size of the tumor before chemo? It also seems I fall between stage 2b and 3a depending on where I look if I go with my original size tumor.  I appreciate any thoughts on this. Leslie Dx 5/29/2008, ILC, 5cm, Stage IIB, Grade 1, 1/13 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2010 08:12PM - edited Aug 14, 2010 08:21PM by lamuso Congrats geewhiz!  Isn't a great feeling leaving the oncologist after a good appointment?  I feel on top of the world!  I'd like to know more about the green vegetable juice......... I love my veges and eat many servings a day but it would be nice to get them in juice.  I took a yoga class last fall, my first one ever, and I plan to sign up again for it in September.  By the way, I was told I have a 15% chance of recurrance and I am also 3A.   Take care!
Posts.Title: Had a great visit with my oncologist! geewhiz geewhiz

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2009 11:43PM lamuso wrote: Hi Karen.  So glad to hear you made it through your first chemo today.  It is all so new and every treatment seems a bit easier than the last.  The week of my first chemo my youngest daughter graduated high school and we had a huge grad party taking place Friday of that week at our house.  For me, the hardest days were the 3rd and 4th day after treatment.  I was pretty tired and it seemed my stomach would be a bit unsettled those days.  Then I would fly throught the next week and a half feeling fine.  You will get through all of this and look back at it just as I am.  I finished chemo last October, then had surgery with radiation following.  I am now planning my reconstructive surgery for next month.  It is all pretty overwhelming and that is a normal feeling.  Take care and know that you are not alone.  There are wonderful women on this site that have answered many questions for me.  You will find this site a great support and comfort.  Remember to take of yourself with lots of rest (and comfort food!) Leslie :)
Posts.Title: New Comer AsiaYM victoriasecret

Posts.Content: lamuso wrote: Can anyone tell me if they had problems with their lymphedema getting worse after reconstructive surgery?  I'm scheduled for a lat dorsi flap with expander (just expander on opposite side).  I have mild lymphedema and keep it controlled with my sleeve when I need it and massage.  My ps told me it should not make things flair up but I am still concerned.  Anyone have experience with this?
